question: What is the primary role of the Java Virtual Machine (JVM)?

choices.0: To compile Java source code into bytecode.
choices.1: To execute Java bytecode on a specific platform.
choices.2: To manage Java libraries and APIs.
choices.3: To provide development tools for Java applications.

question: Which command is used to compile a Java source file named \texttt{MyClass.java}?
What is the most common and standard correct signature for the \texttt{main} method in a Java application?
Which component provides the runtime environment for executing Java applications, but does not include development tools?

You have a compiled Java class file named \texttt{MyApp.class} located in the directory \texttt{/home/user/java/bin}. You are currently in the directory \texttt{/home/user}. Which command will correctly execute \texttt{MyApp}?
What happens if you try to compile a Java source file that contains a syntax error?

choices.0: The program will compile but throw a runtime exception.
choices.1: The compiler will generate a warning but produce a \texttt{.class} file.
choices.2: The compiler will report an error and not produce a \texttt{.class} file.
choices.3: The JVM will attempt to fix the error during execution.

question: Which of the following statements about the \texttt{main} method is true?

choices.0: It must always be declared as \texttt{public final}.
choices.1: It can return any primitive type.
choices.2: It is the entry point for a Java application.
choices.3: It can be overloaded with different parameters and still be the application entry point.

question: What is the primary purpose of the \texttt{CLASSPATH} environment variable or the \texttt{-cp} command-line option?

choices.0: To specify the location of Java source files.
choices.1: To specify the location of Java executable files (like \texttt{java} and \texttt{javac}).
choices.2: To specify the directories where the JVM should look for \texttt{.class} files and \texttt{.jar} files.
choices.3: To specify the version of the Java Development Kit to use.

question: Which of the following are valid declarations for the \texttt{main} method in a Java application?
What is the primary difference between JDK and JRE?

choices.0: JDK is for executing Java applications, while JRE is for developing them.
choices.1: JDK includes development tools (like \texttt{javac}), while JRE only includes the runtime environment (JVM and libraries).
choices.2: JRE includes the Java compiler, while JDK does not.
choices.3: JDK is platform-independent, while JRE is platform-dependent.

question: You compile a Java file \texttt{App.java} which contains a class \texttt{com.example.App}. The compiled \texttt{.class} file is located in the \texttt{project/bin/com/example/} directory. To run this class from the \texttt{project} directory, which command would you use?
Which of the following are true statements regarding the Java compilation and execution process?

choices.1: The JVM directly executes \texttt{.java} source files.
choices.2: Java bytecode is designed to be platform-independent.
choices.3: The \texttt{java} command requires a \texttt{.class} file to execute a Java application.
choices.4: The JIT compiler translates bytecode into native machine code during runtime to improve performance.

question: You have a Java application with multiple classes. One of them, \texttt{MainApp.java}, contains the \texttt{main} method. If you compile all files successfully and then try to run \texttt{MainApp} using \texttt{java MainApp}, but you get a \texttt{NoClassDefFoundError} for another class, \texttt{HelperClass}, what is the most likely reason?

choices.0: \texttt{HelperClass.java} was not compiled into a \texttt{.class} file.
choices.1: \texttt{HelperClass.class} is not found in the classpath at runtime.
choices.2: The \texttt{main} method in \texttt{MainApp} has an incorrect signature.
choices.3: There is a syntax error in \texttt{HelperClass.java} that was somehow missed during compilation.

question: Which of the following statements are true regarding the Java Development Kit (JDK)?

choices.0: It includes the Java Runtime Environment (JRE).
choices.2: It is strictly required to run any Java application.
choices.3: It includes tools for debugging and monitoring Java applications (e.g., \texttt{jconsole}, \texttt{jvisualvm}).
choices.4: The JDK itself is platform-independent, meaning one JDK installation works on any operating system.

choices.3: Compilation Error, as a single file cannot contain multiple classes.

question: What is the consequence of declaring a class as \texttt{public} in a Java source file when the file name does not exactly match the public class name (e.g., \texttt{MyFile.java} contains \texttt{public class MyClass})?

choices.0: The compilation will succeed, but a runtime error will occur when trying to load the class.
choices.1: The compilation will succeed with a warning, and the program will run normally.
choices.2: The compilation will fail with an error.
choices.3: The \texttt{public} keyword will be ignored by the compiler, and the class will be treated as package-private.

choices.3: The program will compile and run, treating the single \texttt{String} as the first argument.

question: Which of the following statements about the \texttt{main} method in Java are true?

choices.0: A Java class can have multiple \texttt{main} methods with different parameter types (overloading).
choices.1: The \texttt{main} method must always be declared in a \texttt{public} class.
choices.2: The order of \texttt{public}, \texttt{static}, and \texttt{void} in the \texttt{main} method signature does not affect its validity.
choices.3: The \texttt{main} method can throw checked exceptions without being caught or declared.
choices.4: The \texttt{args} parameter can be named anything, not necessarily \texttt{args}.

question: Consider a Java class \texttt{MainRunner} with a \texttt{main} method. If you execute \texttt{java -Dmy.prop=value MainRunner arg1 arg2}, which of the following are true?

choices.0: The string \texttt{"my.prop=value"} will be the first element in the \texttt{args} array.
choices.1: The \texttt{args} array will contain two elements: \texttt{"arg1"} and \texttt{"arg2"}.
choices.2: You can retrieve the value \texttt{"value"} using \texttt{System.getProperty("my.prop")}.
choices.3: The \texttt{-D} option is a standard command-line argument passed to the \texttt{main} method.
choices.4: The \texttt{main} method will execute even if \texttt{MainRunner.class} is not in the current directory, provided it's in the classpath.

choices.0: To define the main entry point of a Java application.
choices.1: To group related classes and interfaces, providing a naming convention and access protection.
choices.2: To compile Java source code into bytecode.
choices.3: To execute Java applications on the Java Virtual Machine.
